Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the matter moot if the removal date has passed while an application for permanent residency remains unresolved?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Lewis lived in Canada without authorization and sought to defer her removal. Her request was denied, and although her humanitarian and compassionate grounds application is pending, the removal date passed.
Crimes.Court_Ruling: The case is moot because the removal date has passed
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failed to leave Canada by the removal date
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations due to domestic abuse
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Mootness doctrine in judicial review proceedings
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Timing of removal date relative to ongoing immigration applications
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review after missed removal deadline
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable – issue determined on procedural grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order, visa status, H&C application record
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 112 of IRPA (removal orders), Section 25(1) (H&C applications)
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for deferral based on pending H&C application
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Existence and status of H&C application, compliance with removal order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and opportunity to remain pending H&C decision
Crimes.Governing_Rule: A case may be dismissed as moot if the removal date has passed, even if related applications remain pending
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None identified; dismissal based on mootness, not evidence
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential hardship from removal during pending H&C process
Crimes.Cause_Description: Ms. Lewis overstayed her visitor's visa and faced removal after a domestic abuse incident brought her to CBSA's attention
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Court acknowledged pending H&C file but found no live controversy
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44(1) of IRPA – being inadmissible for remaining beyond authorized period
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: No dispute over factual basis of unauthorized stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Court jurisdiction over moot immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Factual record accepted; legal issue focused on justiciability
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No practical effect of court decision given expired removal date
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness in administrative and immigration law context

Crimes.Violation_Type: Visa overstay leading to exclusion order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the matter moot when the removal date passes, despite an unresolved humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Lewis overstayed her visa, was issued an exclusion order, and her PRRA application was denied. Her request for deferral of removal was denied, and the removal date passed before judicial review.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal pending H&C application
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Case is moot due to passed removal date
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national with expired temporary resident status
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Remained in Canada after visa expiration without applying for extension
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Pending humanitarian and compassionate application based on personal circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Doctrine of mootness in judicial review
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Continuing viability of relief sought post-removal date
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing of judicial review following failed deferral request
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not assessed – decision based on procedural mootness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa records, removal order, PRRA denial, H&C application status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 44(1) IRPA (overstay), Section 112 (removal order), Section 25(1) (H&C discretion)
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request to defer removal due to pending H&C application
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Status of visa, validity of removal order, pendency of H&C claim
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Suspension of removal and right to remain during H&C processing
Crimes.Governing_Rule: A case may be dismissed as moot if the removal date has passed, even if an H&C application remains unresolved
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None identified – dismissal not based on lack of evidence
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of separation from family and community due to removal
Crimes.Cause_Description: Ms. Lewis lived in Canada illegally after her visa expired and did not apply to extend it, leading to an exclusion order and removal proceedings
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed file but found no live issue due to elapsed removal date
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44(1) of IRPA – remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: No challenge to authenticity or completeness of records
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Court’s ability to intervene after removal window has closed
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Factual basis undisputed; legal focus on justiciability
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No effective remedy possible after removal date has passed
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness doctrine applied to immigration judicial reviews
